channel.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
channel.description:
[center][size=10pt]I've wanted to be able to have what I could legitimately call my OWN private server for a while now. I don't mean making my own base, etc., just to do what I want to plan out without any or much help at all. The way I'm seeing this, it's time to stop dicking around, and learn the F'ing language that RSPS use so I can at least understand what I'm doing. I am reading java docs, taking notes in notepad of whatever seems very important in the language, and even made myself another notepad to put things in that I should read a few times a day, or study, lol. Still though, I'm having trouble. How do I know what's good to study? Just a few (around 20) general rules/facts about java and read them a few times a day or what? My brain isn't fully developed, I'm 15. The cannabis and alcohol doesn't help either. :| :cool: :( :mad:
To the point, do you guys have some general tips/rules I should stick by while trying to learn java to increase my learning productivity?[/size][/center]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

PI_Developer:

My brain isn’t fully developed, I’m 15. The cannabis and alcohol doesn’t help either. :mad:

Read full topic
item.source: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @PI_Developer PI_Developer
item.description:
@PI_Developer wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:17, topic:524459”]The way I learned programming was by thinking of a project I’d personally use, then making it and researching stuff I didn’t know anything about.
Also, until you’re a bit older you might wanna consider laying of the drugs, or at least moderating it.[/quote]
I appreciate the idea. I like your method. It seems a lot better of a learning experience, not the general sh*t, like college.
The drugs, oh yes. When I was in 6th grade (where I lived at the time was my last year of elementary), I got 52 of 53 questions right on my math state test, so I am very smart, but I can see the dope decreasing my ability to learn.
I love the intuition the pot brings me though

Read full topic
item.source: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

The way I learned programming was by thinking of a project I’d personally use, then making it and researching stuff I didn’t know anything about.
Also, until you’re a bit older you might wanna consider laying of the drugs, or at least moderating it.

Read full topic
item.source: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

% is known as the modulo operator. It divides one number by another number and gives you the remainder.

If you do a % b, you will be given the remainder of a/b

Read full topic
item.source: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @PI_Developer PI_Developer
item.description:
@PI_Developer wrote:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:14, topic:524459”][quote author=PI_Developer link=topic=643001.msg4329376#msg4329376 date=1373451710]

There’s actually loads that you’ll find hard to understand/not get a good enough explanation.

of problems or guides?

both

Shit man, you trying to bomb me?

DT: if one of you could tell me how to declare ‘multiples’, I think I could get this problem down. Help!

finding out if a number is a multiple of another number is easy in programming. all you do is divide and see if there’s a remainder.

/**
* Checks if x is a multiple of y
**/
boolean isMultipleOf(int x, int y) {
    return y % x == 0; // % divides and returns the remainder. if there is no remainder, then the number is a multiple
}

That comment right there just made me hate you and love you at the same time
[/quote]

Lol? which comment?[/quote]
The one that helped me but clearly proved im a dumb ass

Edit: Just spoonfeed me dude. At least Ill know what to do next time

3, 5, all multiples under 1000 added. :c

Read full topic

item.source: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“PI_Developer, post:6, topic:524459”][quote author=tigerclan link=topic=643001.msg4329357#msg4329357 date=1373447975]
Read The Java Tutorials.

But in order to actually know how to program, you have to make things that are actually useful. Making a basic Java boilerplate and having it print basic shit isn’t going to teach you anything.

I’ve found Project Euler to be really helpful. It teaches you how to apply your programming skills to real problems. Although these are only mathematical questions, they require you to know how to use conditional statements, loops, and a variety of variable types. Also, some of these problems seem simple until you try to solve them and realize the simple solution won’t run in a reasonable amount of time, so it also teaches you how to optimize your code.

I dunno about application tutorials(making applets and GUIs, etc) for Java, but I’m sure someone around here will have some insight.
[/quote]
Thanks a lot bud, I’m sure this will help me a lot

Edit: I’m on the easiest one, have NO idea wtf to do. This may take a few years…

Reading javadocs is of almost no use if you don’t even know how to program java. Are you familiar with the syntax and keywords and stuff?

No. I’m a crisp, clean, unmarked, white sheet of paper, on an organized, neat desk. :([/quote]

Then google “Java basic beginner tutorials”

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @PI_Developer PI_Developer
item.description:
@PI_Developer wrote:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:4, topic:524459”]Read The Java Tutorials.

But in order to actually know how to program, you have to make things that are actually useful. Making a basic Java boilerplate and having it print basic shit isn’t going to teach you anything.

I’ve found Project Euler to be really helpful. It teaches you how to apply your programming skills to real problems. Although these are only mathematical questions, they require you to know how to use conditional statements, loops, and a variety of variable types. Also, some of these problems seem simple until you try to solve them and realize the simple solution won’t run in a reasonable amount of time, so it also teaches you how to optimize your code.

I dunno about application tutorials(making applets and GUIs, etc) for Java, but I’m sure someone around here will have some insight.[/quote]
Thanks a lot bud, I’m sure this will help me a lot

Edit: I’m on the easiest one, have NO idea wtf to do. This may take a few years…

Yesteryear:

Reading javadocs is of almost no use if you don’t even know how to program java. Are you familiar with the syntax and keywords and stuff?

No. I’m a crisp, clean, unmarked, white sheet of paper, on an organized, neat desk.

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

Read The Java Tutorials.

But in order to actually know how to program, you have to make things that are actually useful. Making a basic Java boilerplate and having it print basic shit isn’t going to teach you anything.

I’ve found Project Euler to be really helpful. It teaches you how to apply your programming skills to real problems. Although these are only mathematical questions, they require you to know how to use conditional statements, loops, and a variety of variable types. Also, some of these problems seem simple until you try to solve them and realize the simple solution won’t run in a reasonable amount of time, so it also teaches you how to optimize your code.

I dunno about application tutorials(making applets and GUIs, etc) for Java, but I’m sure someone around here will have some insight.

Read full topic
item.source: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]

item.title: Any advice on quick learning, or advice in general? [Java]
item.dc:creator: @PI_Developer PI_Developer
item.description:
@PI_Developer wrote:

JavaLearner:

Make enough exercices. Simply reading things won’t help you. You need to develop some sort of insight, so that when you tackle a problem, you know how to handle it.

Thanks, I appreciate the idea.
Still, I feel like I do better with direction. Would you give me some assignments that I could tackle from reading javadocs?

Read full topic
